Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Graphene-enabled Synthesis and Surface Modification of Water Separation Membranes

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1351430
Mi

This proposed project is designed to examine a relatively new material, graphene oxide nanomaterial's (GO), as a possible solution to desalination and for purifying impaired waters. By impaired waters, it refers to waters that may be contaminated with anthropogenic (made by people) chemicals. Graphene oxide membranes are thought to increase the rate at which water permeates (goes through) the membrane. This means that salt rejection is more controlled by pore size that semi-permeable membranes that are presently used in desalination. Nanomaterials are an extremely active area of research and they hold out the promise of revolutionizing many fields of science and engineering.

The research will:

(1) for the first time experimentally characterize aqueous-phase water transport through GO nanochannels, thereby filling the gap of our knowledge about the use of GO nanomaterials for highly efficient water separation;
(2) offer novel routes to the synthesis and surface modification of water separation membranes; and
(3) fundamentally elucidate the transport and photocatalytic mechanisms for the removal of targeted water contaminants by GO-enabled membranes.

The proposed strategies for GO-based membrane synthesis and surface modification are facile, highly scalable, and potentially become a standard for the incorporation of GO into various membrane materials. Once these membranes are better understood, they will find widespread applications such as point-of-use water purification, on-site treatment of hydrofracking flowback water, renewable energy production, and drug delivery and artificial organ development.

To help to disseminate that findings of this research the education plan will emphasize

(1) recruiting underrepresented groups to promote greater diversity in the environmental workforce, and
(2) participating in public exhibitions to raise environmental awareness among a much wider audience. The adopted active learning pedagogy has the potential to transform engineering sustainability education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Membrane processes are among the most effective strategies to address water-energy nexus problems.   However, today’s membrane-based water separation in general suffers from membrane fouling, low chlorine resistance, low selectivity, high capital and operational costs, etc. Therefore, it is very desirable to discover new materials to make high-performance membranes that will solve these problems. The goal of career project is thus to use novel 2D nanomaterials (e.g., graphene, graphene oxide/GO) and innovative methods to synthesize the next-generation, high-performance membranes. In addition, this project focuses on exploring basic science questions and expand my research into exciting yet challenging applications such as solar-powered desalination.

The results from this project have greatly contributed to the scientific understanding of GO membranes. We developed a new characterization approach that allows us to understand membrane swelling in both aqueous solutions as well as in organic solvents.  Such fundamental understanding of the GO material will enable new synthesis strategies that allow us to optimize GO membrane performance in applications such as water purification, wastewater reuse, and pharmaceutical and petrochemical separations. The importance and outcomes of our research in this area has been well recognized by the scientific community. For example, our top 5 cited articles on GO membranes have been cited more than 2000 times. I was twice invited by Science editors to write perspective articles on GO membrane (Mi, Science 2014, 343 740 and Mi, Science 2019, 364, 1033). Our research on GO membranes has led to one US patent and will very likely pave the way to the development of GO-based membrane technology that lead to environmental, economic, and social benefits.

Our work on 2D lamellar membranes in the past five years led to one patent, 17 peer-reviewed publications, and 65 invited seminar, plenary and keynote presentations, contributed talks, and posters. In addition, the research results were disseminated to the public through media articles and interviews, and by participating in Competitions (e.g., Big Ideas, Global Desalination Challenge, and Solar Desalination Prize) and won two Big Ideas honorable mentions and one grand prize. This project has provided funding and training opportunities to three PhD students, four MS students, and numerous undergraduate students. Additionally, the research materials from this project were incorporated into a variety of graduate and undergraduate classes on technology innovation and sustainability.
